course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Introduction to Economics
course.description: This course provides an overview of both microeconomics and macroeconomics. It demonstrates how tools of economics can be applied for analyzing socioeconomic changes and the effects of government policies. Topics for the applications are China-related and carry global relevance.
course.exclusions: ECON 2103, ECON 2113, ECON 2123, ECON 3113, ECON 3133

reviews.author: samyeung36
reviews.title: Good CC If you want to minor in business don't study this,go take Econ 2113/Econ 2103
reviews.comment_content:
Basic stuff, mainly focus on the macro,because prof. said it is related to your daily life.If you studied DSE Econ ,the content is only 30% new  to you.
Content including: supply and demand,opportunity cost ,marginal benefit and cost,GDP,interest rate ,money supply ,consumption function ,planned aggregate expenditure,Federal Reserve,function of money.
****Inside job (a movie explaining the 2008 financial crisis)***
You will watch it in class after the midterm exam and it is included in the final exam.Ask YouTube if you don't understand the movie.
(recommended video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uM19CBGhhas )
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. accent is hard to listen if you are not good in English like me.He speak supper fast and quite .Better sit in the front and listen carefully.

Poor hand writing,always write out of screen without realizing when using the projector.

*******Highly recommended to take all the lessons since some of the content will appear in the exam(eg essay )******

*******Check assignment questions in class ,better go if you are not 100% sure you do it correctly .And some questions is just not so good to answer because it is waste of your time and totally not likely to be tested in the exam.**************
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments: 16%. 2% for each assignment up to a maximum of 8 assignments,total 14 assignment
*(answer will not be graded)* *(Check answer in class)*
Midterm 34%(Mcs,1 essay)  Final 50% (Mcs,1 essay)
The mean is around B-

Midterm 60/72 mean 54 SD 8
Final mc 79/95 mean 61.96 median 62.00 SD 12.35
      essay 8/8  mean 4.88 median 6 SD 2.79
Final grade=A-(i got lv4 in dse econ)
reviews.comment_workload:
1 assignment every week(you can hand in only 8 out of 14 to get the full marks.)(you can do the rest on your own and not hand it in)
It takes me more than half an hour to finish all the problems .Because it required you to draw diagram.
Go through all the ppt. and problem sets before exam are highly recommended.

reviews.author: AMZN
reviews.comment_content:
Basic economics course for students who didn't study this subject before. I highly recommend students with engineering/science background to register this course as most of the content are so useful in daily life. As I didn't study economics before, some chapters such as federal reserve and interest rate are just mind-blown for me.

Most topics are focused on macro-economic with few introductory chapters relate to micro-economic. One and a half lecture is to watch a movie "Inside jobs" regarding the financial crisis in 2008, which would be the examination content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His teaching followed the power-point material with some additional explanation, actually you can read the power-point at home and google the terminology if you wanna skip lessons.

The teaching speed was just alright at first few lessons. But after the first mid-term, he suddenly speed up a lot and skipped many slides if he didn't interest on it.
reviews.comment_grading:
At the first lesson, Carsten stated the mean of this course is around B-, but it seems that the grading is better than this due to the special arrangement in this semester.

Assignment: 8/8
My 1st mid-term: 53/60 (mean: 45 SD: 7)
My 2nd mid-term: 57/60 (mean: 42.11 SD: 7.98)
I didn't take final exam as it is optional in this semester

Overall: A
My friend got a B+ although his score on the two mid-terms were around the mean.
reviews.comment_workload:
Totally 10 weekly assignments but you can get full marks by finishing 8 out of 10. He didn't check the quality of your assignments, and you can get full marks by just submitting "something" on canvas. He will give the answers every week after the submission date. However, I still did most assignment questions every week as it is good for mid-term revision.

Mid terms are not difficult even thought I didn't take econ in HKDSE. Studying the power-point is good enough to get high marks.

reviews.author: tooooooo
reviews.title: not bad cc
reviews.comment_content: see other. i think it is interesting to know something about the economics, and professor let us watch a movie, which describe the reasons of financial crisis. it is quite inspirational. the movie name is "inside job". if you want to watch first, you can, but i am not sure is it required now
reviews.comment_teaching: professor explains concept clearly and the concept is not some difficult stuff. even if you like me don't have any economic background will be fine.
reviews.comment_grading: fair grading. mean is not soooo high. i got above mean a little bit. got a b+
reviews.comment_workload:
not large. just assignment each week which u can simply type anything u want to submit, and u got marks, it is like to make sure you have do something.
mc midterm and final, aroung 40 mc. not accumulative. time limit is tight, need to do fast, but if you do revision and understand the concept, you should at least get mean ( mean is like 25 out of 40? forgot)
no attandance

reviews.author: Frankie:)
reviews.title: U willl be in disadvantage if u haven't studied high school econs before
reviews.comment_content:
I can say half of the course content will be the same with the things learnt in high school economics like opportunities costs, CPI, inflation, Nominal GDP.....But there are some new stuff like autonomous expenditures,the film"inside job" so on and so forth.
   To be frank,the course content is easy if u have time to study it
reviews.comment_teaching: I skipped most of his lecture since I have to allocate more time to my major course study.
reviews.comment_grading:
i can say the grade is good if u have econs background before,here is my score for your reference.
Midterm 1 (optional) 29/42. Mean 30/42 SD 3.2
Midterm 2 (optional) 32/42 mean 35/42  SD 3.3
Final(mandatory) 31/70 mean 44/70 SD 8.7
  my letter grade is C+
As a student without econs background,and with 18 credits taken in this fall sem,cannot manage to score high in this courseğŸ˜­
reviews.comment_workload: Very light.2 assignment per week.As long as u hand them in u score full mark no matter your answer is correct or not

reviews.author: thebusranger
reviews.title: Never attend when Han Li is the instructor
reviews.comment_content: Typical economics knowledge, 60-70% from DSE syllabus. However the question types are not similar to DSE question at all.
reviews.comment_teaching: strong mainland accent. I hate this so i nearly skip all the lectures and study the materials on my own
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite good.
I get full mark in the pop up quiz and scored around mean in both midterm and final exam. It turns out to be a B.
reviews.comment_workload:
Moderate
HW is the thing that is granted for marks, there are sources in the internet and you don't need to waste time to do it. Everyone scored nearly full mark in it.
Remember to prepare for pop up quiz
No matter you have studied econ before, do spend some time on revision and do exercise. Even though I have study economics, I need to spend some time to revise the materials, or else you will fuck up in exam

reviews.author: Misaki
reviews.title: Good Professor and Good Grade
reviews.comment_content:
FB 1 Thinking Like an Economist
FB 2 Comparative Advantage
FB 3 Supply and Demand
FB 4 Macroeconomics: The Birdâ€™s-Eye View of the Economy
FB 5 Measuring Economic Activity: GDP and Unemployment
FB 6 Measuring the Price Level and Inflation
FB 7 Economic Growth, Productivity, and Living Standards
FB 8 The Labor Market: Workers, Wages, and Unemployment
FB 9 Saving and Capital Formation
FB 10 Money, Prices, and the Federal Reserve
FB 11 Financial Markets and International Capital Flows
FB 12 Short-Terms Economic Fluctuations: An Introduction
FB 13 Spending and Output in the Short Run
FB 14 Stabilizing the Economy: The Role of the Fed
FB 15 Aggregate Demand, Aggregate Supply, and Inflation
FB 16 International Trade and Trade Policy
FB 17 Exchange Rates and the Open Economy

Movie watching: Inside Job

The content is mostly related to macroeconomics. For the first 10 chapters, it is easy to catch up. However, it will be more difficult starting from chapter 10 as more professional terms and concepts will be included from chapter 10-17. It also includes a film-watching about the financial crisis in 2008, which was also tested in the final exam.

For this semester, chapter 16 was skipped.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is very nice and helpful, and he is willing to answer the questions raised by us. The lesson is separated into two sessions, the first half for explaining the assignment and then go through the content. He usually likes to give a summary for each chapter by writing on his tablet and then go through the PowerPoint.
reviews.comment_grading:
24% for the normal assignment
8% for the mini-assignment
19% x2 for midterms (Optional)(Two midterms for this course)
30% for the final(Compulsory)

If you do not attend the midterm exam, the weight for the final exam will increase.

Midterm and Final are all mc questions.

There will be some advantages for the people who studied Economics in DSE before, and this course does not exclude the people who studied Economics.

My result:
Assignments: full
Midterm 1: 34/42(Mean:29.98 SD:5.39)
Midterm 2: 39/42(Mean:33.17 SD:5.3)
Final: 59/70(Mean:43.2 SD:9.15)

Overall: A
reviews.comment_workload:
There are 2 assignments every week, one mini-assignment and one normal assignment, and you are required to do at least 8 mini-assignments and 8 normal assignments respectively. Whenever you submitted your assignment, you will be given a full mark no matter your answer is right or wrong. However, if you really pay effort into doing the assignment, the workload will be heavy. In the final exam, there are also several questions related to the mini -assignment. If you did not pay effort in doing the assignment, you may not get the answer.

For midterms and final, it only takes 2-3 days for studying will be enough if you understand the concept.

reviews.author: Anonymous^^
reviews.comment_content:
Itâ€™s easy if youâ€™ve taken Economics in DSE. Itâ€™s just basic knowledge of economics with a few US examples sometimes.

But it may be hard to catch up if you havenâ€™t studied economics before as it contained 3-year content in DSE Economics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I only attended the first few lectures. Heâ€™s kinda humorous with straight face.

He is not a very forceful person to make students do all the work. No attendance taken so you can rely completely rely on yourself to study if you find studying on your own is more effective. (Iâ€™ve done that.)
reviews.comment_grading:
Basically just get some of your assignment done then he will give a full mark. You donâ€™t even need to complete the whole thing or get the answers right. It is just to encourage you to get some practices.

There are 2 midterms in total. You can opt to take either one or all-in final. All MC questions. They are not really difficult if you took Econ comics in DSE before.

If you are slightly more hard working to read the textbook (not needed if you only want a B range tho), you can get an A range. He did not give A+ though.

I didnâ€™t really have a final exam even there meant to be one originally.
reviews.comment_workload: Not a big workload at all as you donâ€™t have to complete all questions, even though he gives you a piece of assignment every week.

reviews.author: leungyee
reviews.title: Good course!
reviews.comment_content:
Actually this course teach us about the basic of economic. We learn most of them in our high school(DSE). They are not very difficult and I am able to learn them even I skipped some lessons. (I have not studied any economic course in my high school and I skipped some classes, but I can still learn them by myself like searching in google or ask friend or even just study the lecture notes, but I can still get a full understand about the economic concept that the lesson talked about)
And I know that there are some students who studied economic in high school studied this course. But do not worry about you may get lower marks if you have not studied in your high school as you can also get a good grade if you study well.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor teaching quite well. He explained the point, the knowledge clearly. The lecture notes are also very detail. All economic terms and  knowlegde like opportunity costs, supply and demand curve... explained very detail in words and examples. I believed that if you skip the class, you may still understand the notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment: 16%
Midtern:34%(can skip and all in final)
Final:50%
You can get full mark in assignments even you do not how to do, prof do not check the answer. So remember to submit. Easy marks!
I skipped the midterm exam and the marks all counted by final exam. Finally I reached the mean in final exam and got full marks in assignment. I got B- . Grading is nice, but I am lazy.lol
reviews.comment_workload: Light. Although there is 1 assignment per week. If you just submit it with all wrong answers, you can still get full marks. You can only submit 8 assignments, you still can full marks which is 14%.

reviews.author: PPWong
reviews.title: almost the same as DSE
reviews.comment_content: The content is almost the same as DSE economics. Some detailed wordings or explanation in some topics might be different. A movie is included as content material at the end of the course and a few questions  in the final exam are about the movie
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor's teaching is good in terms of content with examples and organization, but the tone might sound dull and boring if you are not highly concentrated.
Reading the lecture powerpoints and adequate exercise might be enough already.
reviews.comment_grading:
Easy if you have taken Economics in DSE, or the course would be competitive
Both mid-term and final exam are MC only.
reviews.comment_workload: Around one assignment a week. Not all of them are necessarily done.

reviews.author: Nathan Hau
reviews.title: A Great Introduction to Macroeconomics
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers the basics of macroeconomics,designed for those who are new to economics. The specific topics covered are covered in other reviews so check there, but in general they are within the DSE economics and AP macroeconomics syllabus.
For this reason there is abundant coverage of these topics online, so I would say you won't have a hard time grasping these concepts.
The addition of the film Inside Job gives you a glimpse into the 2008 financial crisis and the dark side of the financial sector, which is pretty fascinating IMO.
The goal of this course is to help you understand the economic news you see everyday, so I would say the content of this course is adequate.
reviews.comment_teaching: I personally enjoyed Holz's teaching, the pace is good, clear explanation with real life examples sprinkled in. He also fill in the gaps and holes in the lecture powerpoint so i think going to lectures is pretty crucial. Either that or read the textbook and look stuff up online.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignment:16%
Mid-term:34%
Final:50%
OR
Assignment:16%
Final:80%(skipping mid-term)
The grading system is not clear to students, Holz mentioned it's neither strictly absolute grading nor based on curve but a mix of both (or something along those lines, can't remember), so I can only speak for myself.
I have no economics background but still got a pretty good grade so I would say the grading is pretty good (obv. not representative)
Assignment:Full
Mid-term:73/75
Final:94/100
Grade:A
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is pretty light, ~8 questions for each chapter, 1 assignment per week.
You only need to complete 8 out of 11/12 assignments assigned to get full marks, and you'll get full mark for each assignment by just attempting to complete, doesn't even need to be correct (which is SUPER lenient).
Though of course to better understand the topics you should complete all of them.

Course Description: This course introduces the fundamental theories of microeconomics and macroeconomics. Topics include consumer theory, producer theory, the behavior of firms, market equilibrium, monopoly, the role of the government in the economy, long-run economic growth, the monetary system, and the open-economy macroeconomics.
Intended Learning Outcomes:
On completion of the course, students are expected to be able to:
â€¢ Understand the basic logic of economic reasoning;
â€¢ Apply basic economic analysis to explain and predict economic relationships;
â€¢ Have a deeper understanding of economic issues and events;
â€¢ Make critical evaluations on views and opinions related to economics.
Readings:
â€¢ The required textbook is Principles of Economics, 6e (2012) by N. Gregory Mankiw,
which is available at the bookstore and also reserved in the library. You are also encouraged to browse the authorâ€™s blog (http://gregmankiw.blogspot.com/) and read economic and social news.
Grading: 15% Two pop-up quizzes 35% Midterm exam (June 28)
50% Comprehensive final exam


Course Outline:
Note: This is a preliminary list of topics; I may add topics, remove topics or switch the order of topics depending on how the class is progressing.
I. Introduction: basic principles of economics
II. The market system of demand and supply
III. How price regulations and tax policies affect the outcomes of the market
IV. Basic welfare analysis of tax policy
V. The problem areas for the market and government policies to deal with market failure VI. Competition, monopoly, and the organization of industry
VII. The market for labor
IX. Basic concepts in macroeconomics
VIII. Economic growth
X. The monetary system
XI. Basic concepts of open-economy macroeconomics (if time permits)

reviews.author: AdityaDas
reviews.comment_content:
Very Basic Economic topics like supply demand cost production function taxes inflation trade.
Content of the course is very easy. Almost everything is in the PPT slides.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor teaches very slow and has a mainland accent which makes it very difficult to understand what she is saying. Lectures are very boring.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair. Mean doesn't do very high.
reviews.comment_workload:
There were 4 Problem sets in the whole course and got 1 week time to do it.
Remember to prepare beforehand for the pop-up quiz.
The mid term and final are not very difficult. You will be able to do it easily if you have understood the basic concepts of each topic.

reviews.author: UnconMarketeers
reviews.comment_content:
Typical microeconomics course. The only "macroeconomics" part is to know how to calculate gdp and cpi and understand their difference.

I guess in summer, the amount of content is  not as many as in regular semester, but given that the exam time is 2 days after last lecture, things seem to be fair again.
reviews.comment_teaching: What I can say for this part is that, you may study the content without paying attention to lecture, because there is very little useful information spoken in the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% homework -2 assignments in whole semester. Although answers of assignment can be found online, I have to mention two things:
1. For the second assignment, the release day was 2 days before exam, deadline was 1 day before exam, and the answer was given 2 hours before exam.
2. Although I believe most students get full marks, no personal or global statistics are distributed for second assignments.

10% attendance - Again unclear. No concrete method of calculating attendance is provided.

40% midterm and 40% final - Both exams contain conceptual questions where most of them are simple. Again, for the final, individual grade and global grade distributions are unknown.

Given so many unknown components, fortunately my final grade is one of the few things that I can know. Based on my grade, this course offers a lenient grading scheme in overall.
reviews.comment_workload: You may say the course has low workload because some content is cut from the original syllabus, as well as the difficulty of exam is relatively low (No heavy calculations, most questions are simple and conceptual-based). But in terms  of the fast pace, it lifts up the workload of this summer course.

reviews.author: PaulKing
reviews.comment_content: Pretty much cover most of the high school DSE economics contents. The topics do not involve much calculation, but other than fundamental concepts, topics like capital /banking system will go deeper. It will be pretty easy if you did take econ in high school, but even if u don't, it is still pretty easy to catch up as long as you go through all the notes and assignments.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is pretty nice and patient in answering the question and explaining assignments. Usually he will go through the assignments question at the beginning of the lessons, which is quite helpful for clearing concepts. The teaching is decent, but as long as you can recognize the concept, it's ok to skip the lectures and read on your own.
reviews.comment_grading:
24% for regular assignments
and 8% for mini assignments
There will be an overflow counting on assignments so you don't really have to submit all, but if you want to get familiar with the concepts then it's best to finish all regular ones.

38% for two mid-terms and 30% for final
All exams are in the mode of online multiple-choice questions. Final exam will cover some extra questions from the additional content or readings of assignments (including a movie).
you can choose to only attend the final so the remaining weighting will only count on final. But think twice before you do that cause that means you will bare bigger risk for failing in final.
reviews.comment_workload: Assignments did take some time to finish, but you don't really have to spend too much time on revision or preparing for the exam, 'cause most of the questions that appeared in exams are pretty similar to those in assignments. So just make sure you go through all the assignments and rework on some of the questions and that will be fine to handle the exams.

reviews.author: cabbi
reviews.title: online sem:
reviews.comment_content:
1.10 principles of economics
2.Demand, supply, equilibrium
3.elasticity
4.government policies: price floor/ceiling, tax

reviews.comment_teaching:
professor teaches at a smooth pace and is very willing to answer questions in class. Students are very active and raise lots of questions using zoom (it seems that discussion is promoted when lesson switches to the online mode).
She closely follows the examples in the textbook and sometimes also give some updated analysis of scenarios in life, for example the effect of HK government relief plan during the COVID-19 pandemic.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 hw, 5% each
2 pop-up quizzes, choose the one with the highest score 10%
midterm 25%
final 50%

fair (lenient) grading. Basically knew nothing about economics beforehand but attended lectures and read the textbook. Eventually got A range, much better than expected.
reviews.comment_workload:
Moderate workload. Know nothing about economics before so have to read to the textbook to understand ideas. For students who have a basic understanding of economics the workload should be lighter.

Spent approximately 4-5 hours in finishing each problem set.

The quizzes are unannounced so it is advisable to always be prepared. However I think maybe the professor wants to use the quiz as a mock test for midterms and finals so they came at lecutres approximately before the 2 assessments (not sure about other semesters.)

reviews.comment_teaching: There are many examples help you understand the concepts
reviews.comment_grading:

Final exam: 40%
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair enough
For those who did not learn economics, you have to do all the questions. An expectation of 8~10 questions per week. You may only do some of them and it does not affect the marks of the assignment. See if you can handle all the concepts and skills.

reviews.author: garbage
reviews.title: Good professor!
reviews.comment_content:
Introductory course of economics for people without economic learning background. It is very useful for someone who has not studied economics before.
Textbook: Principles of Macroeconomics 7e by Frank, Bernanke, Antonovics and Heffetz.
The textbook is strongly recommended as it explains the concepts really well and contains a lot of examples based on the true events. It helps you get good grade.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Holz is really a good professor and an excellent scholar. He is very thoughtful. He would not make you do something that you do not like. If you don't like midterms you can choose not to take it, if you do not want to attend classes you can just go. He would also play some course-related youtube videos, which are VERY helpful to your understanding of economics, and he would also explain some economy-related events using the up-to-date newspaper. You can tell that he has put his heart in teaching the course.
reviews.comment_grading:
16% homework, 22% mid term 1, 22% mid term 2, 40% final exam. If you do not take the mid term exams then the final exam would take up 86%.
If you submit homework on time, you get full marks, no matter how terribly you perform in your homework.
the questions in the exams are not difficult, as long as you hit the books
Quiz 1: Mean: 47 SD: 7
Quiz 2: Mean: 44.1 SD:8
I got 57 in quiz 1 and 54 in quiz 2
This semester, according to the recent events, the schemes change a bit, you can choose to take the final exam or all in midterm exams or get a P/F. If all in mid term exam, the mid terms would make up 84% of your final score and I personally chose this grading scheme.
-------------------------------------------------------------The results just came out and I got a B! I just want to say WTF since the grading is really terrible and unacceptable. I got 96% and I got a B!!!!!!! I really did not know what had happened.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Turns out that three people lost 16% because of a mistake, after correcting the mistake, my final grade is an A, 96%. And you can see that less than 80% can still get a B, so pretty good grade!
reviews.comment_workload:
If you have not studied economics before, it would probably be large because you may spend 3 hours a week going through the textbook. If you have studied economics before, it would probably be zero.
Overall the workload is not big and it is completely worth it if you have not studied economics before. It is a very useful CCC.

Homework 10%

The grading is generous. I got B+ for full mark in homework (16%), above mean in both mit-term and final exam.

reviews.author: horseradish
reviews.title: Good grade course if you took DSE econ
reviews.comment_content:
Topics:
1. Thinking Like an Economist (Opportunity cost, marginal benefit, and marginal cost)
2. Comparative Advantage (Production Possibilities Curve)
3. Supply and Demand
4. Spending, Income, and GDP
5. Inflation and the Price Level
6. Wages and Unemployment
7. Economic Growth
8. Saving, Capital Formation, and Financial Markets (New: Public, Private, National savings)
9. Money, Prices, and the Financial System
10. Short-Term Economic Fluctuations (New: some more on unemployment rate and output gap)
11. Spending, Output, and Fiscal Policy
12. Monetary Policy and the Federal Reserve
13. ADAS and Stabilization Policy
14. Exchange Rates, International Trade, and Capital Flows

There is a film about the 2008 financial crisis (Inside Job). 10% of the questions in the final are about the film.

Summary: Mostly DSE Econ, plus something new which won't be too difficult. There is also a film.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor teaches in a fun and engaging way. He has interactions with the class. (finding people to do a demonstration). He doesn't just read the PPT, he elaborates with examples. Those lectures are not at all boring.

A lot of time is spent on discussing assignment answers (they are checked every alternative lecture). It takes up most of the lecture.

Still, he's a good lecturer.

reviews.author: Alexander
reviews.title: Good introductory course for people who have zero background in economics
reviews.comment_content: This course doesn't require any prior knowledge of economics, so it is extremely beginner-friendly. Essentially, this course covers the basics of macro- and microeconomics. By taking this course, you will learn about the principles that govern the behavior of the market and economy as a whole. Furthermore, you will also discuss current and recent economic events.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Holz is great at giving lectures. His speaking is very clear and easy to understand. His lectures follow the textbook extremely faithfully, so you won't miss out on any crucial information if you choose to not attend the lectures. However, Professor Holz frequently incorporates amusing examples or demos that help to grasp the concepts and make the lectures more entertaining.
reviews.comment_grading:
This course uses the following grade distribution:

- Assignments (16%)
- Midterm Exam (34%)
- Final Exam (50%)

Note that midterm exam is optional. If you choose to not take it, then final exam will be worth 84% of the total grade. Assignments are graded based on completion. Both exams are quite simple, as long as go over all the presentations or read the textbook.
Overall, I'd say grading is fair.
reviews.comment_workload: There isn't a lot of workload. There are around 10 assignments, but you only need to complete 8 to get the perfect grade for assignments. Professor Holz is very lenient with assignment grading. You won't lose points for leaving a few questions unanswered or wrong. However, late work is accepted under no conditions. There is no attendance, so all lectures are optional, although I recommend to at least go watch the movie at the end of the semester since it comes out on the final exam. Even the midterm exam is not mandatory.

Two lectures per week. One for assignment discussion and one for teaching.
Sometimes professor will read some news excerpt. But they are not in the exam.

reviews.author: tcwong
reviews.title: Good Common Core Course, even if you've never taken economics before
reviews.comment_content:
The content follows closely to the book "Principles of macroeconomics", which consists of a little microeconomics at first, followed by a considerable amount of macroeconomics. The chapters are as follows:
Ch 1 â€œThinking Like an Economistâ€
Ch 2 â€œComparative Advantageâ€
Ch 3 â€œSupply and Demandâ€
Ch 4 â€œSpending, Income, and GDPâ€
Ch 5 â€œInflation and the Price Levelâ€
Ch 6 â€œWages and Unemploymentâ€
Ch 7 â€œEconomic Growthâ€
Ch 8 â€œSaving, Capital Formation, and Financial Marketsâ€
Ch 9 â€œMoney, Prices, and the Financial Systemâ€
Ch 10 â€œShort-Term Economic Fluctuationsâ€
Ch 11 â€œSpending, Output, and Fiscal Policyâ€
Ch 12 â€œMonetary Policy and the Federal Reserveâ€
Ch 13 â€œAggregate Demand, Aggregate Supply, and Stabilization Policyâ€
Ch 14 â€œExchange Rates, International Trade, and Capital Flowsâ€

Please note that there will also be a compulsory film "Inside Job" about the financial crisis that will be covered in the later parts of the lectures, and will be included in the final examinations.

Although I'm a chemical engineering major, I still found these content to be fairly interesting to me and useful in daily life.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is quite easy going and reasonable, and allows people to self study if they choose so. He also like to crack some jokes sometimes, so the lectures aren't really that boring.

There are 2 lectures per week, one being used to discuss about the answers of the assignments, while the other is used to cover new materials.

It is fairly easy to understand and follow the professor, but he did tend to rush a bit for the last few chapters, so you may have to revise those chapters in particular in case you've missed anything.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading distribution is as follows:
16% assignments (2% per assignment, capped at 8 assignments)
34%/0% mid term (this is optional, if you choose not to take the mid term, the 34% will go directly to the final exam)
50%/84% final exam (This will cover everything taught in the lectures, even the film "Inside Job")

MY GRADE:
Assignments: 16/16
Midterm: 69/75 (Mean = 58.51, S.D. 9.13)
Final Examination: 87/100 (Mean = 69.41, S.D. = 12.63)
Overall: 90.78%
Grade: A

Although you would have an advantage if you've learnt economics in secondary school, it is still definitely possible for you to get a good grade if you haven't.

I've never studied economics before, but I've still managed to get an A in this course. You just have to study the lecture notes carefully, and revise the assignments given to you.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is relatively low. There are weekly assignments in this course, but you only need to finish 8 out of approximately 12 assignments to get full marks (16%).

The assignments will not be graded too, you will receive full marks per assignment just by handing it in, regardless of the answers being correct or not.

reviews.author: MS01
reviews.title: All-in Exam Review to provide alternative information on the grading.
reviews.comment_content:
You can refer to other's comment, just the same as previous semesters.

Personally, I would recommend this course to SENG and SSCI students so that you may get some economics senses, which are useful in your daily life.
reviews.comment_teaching: Although he is a German Professor, his English is easy to understand. The first lesson will discuss the homework, while the second lesson will go through the lecture ppt.
reviews.comment_grading:
My friend and I chose the all-in exam grading policy because both of us had another midterm on the same day.

The final exam is 100 MC questions in 100 minutes.
Mean: 69.41/100; SD: 12.63/100

[Update on 20/12/2018]
My Result
Assignment: 100%
Final Exam: 64/100 (below mean 0.4 SD)
Final Grade: B-

My Friend's Result:
Assignment: 100%
Final Exam: 81/100 (above mean ~1 SD)
Final Grade: B+

P.S. We didn't study economics in our DSE before.
reviews.comment_workload: Very low. You only need to submit 8 assignment out of 12, and the quality is not considered.

reviews.author: scotty
reviews.comment_content: There are 14 chapters covered in this course. It is based from "Principles of Macroeconomics" book by Frank, Robert H., and Ben S. Bernanke. You will learn about Introduction to Economics, Macroeconomics, The Economy in the Long and Short Run, and The International Economy. Overall, the content are really great and not too in-depth to understand more about the economic situation in the world.
reviews.comment_teaching: His PPT files are actually downloaded online from the official book's website. His teaching are rather monotone but he speaks clearly. He will go through the slides really fast and sometimes it's really easy to loose track of what he's explaining and not understanding the rest of the lecture. But since the content is about basic economics that I assume high-schoolers have learnt, his teaching doesn't really matter. Listening to his lecture will definitely help you to understand harder concepts.
reviews.comment_grading: I think the grading is quite good since there are 400 students in this course. The mid-term and final are not that difficult if you study thoroughly and understand the concepts and most importantly MEMORIZE everything. In short, this is an easy A course if you really work hard on it.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. Assignments : 16% (pass/fail) (2% x 8 HWs) Have homework every week that you submit through CANVAS that is based from the textbook's question pages. Yup, you can write down anything you want or even copy from internet as long as you write something you will pass. It's okay if you miss one  cause you will have approx. 12 assignments.
2. Midterm : 34% (MC questions mostly about memorization and 5 short questions if I'm not mistaken). The paper had like almost 100 numbers and had to be finished within 1 hour. You can miss the midterm and opt to add the grading in the final which I would highly discourage because the midterm is way easier than the final.
3. Final : 50% (MC and short questions) Cumulative and rather more difficult than midterm since it covers more chapters. Contains basic calculation and very few difficult questions that you can shoot. After the midterm, he will play a movie about US Financial Crisis in 2007 "The Inside Jobs". Everyone on the previous UST space's review said that the movie will cover almost half of the exam, which is not true. Only 1 question in the essay appeared about this movie. So I would suggest you not spending much time on this.

reviews.author: CyrusL
reviews.comment_content:
Content is heavily based on the textbook "Principles of Macroeconomics", starting with the seven core principles of economics, some microeconomics, before going into macroeconomics, with concepts such as GDP, financial system and economic policy being taught.

Note that the film "Inside Job" will be shown at some point in the course, you are highly recommended to attend that session and make notes; some exam questions will be based on that.
reviews.comment_teaching: The PowerPoint, which closely follows the flow of the textbook, is available on Canvas. The professor may clarify new concepts using some examples; these may not be available on Canvas, but otherwise, the teaching is akin to reading the textbook. If you have no problems finishing the assignments and understanding the textbook, there is honestly not much point in attending the lecture other than the film viewing session.
reviews.comment_grading:
ASSIGNMENTS 16%
There were 14 assignments this semester. However, only 8 submissions (each counting 2%) are required. The assignments will not be graded: you get the full 2% just by submitting your work on Canvas. The professor will go through each assignment during the first lecture after its deadline. Model answers will also be uploaded to Canvas.

MIDTERM 34% [0%]
Comprised of 64 multiple-choice questions and 1 essay question. Covers the first half of the course. You only have 80 minutes to complete the test, so don't waste time on questions for which you lack a concrete solution. [You can choose not to take the midterm: in that case, the final examination will account for 84% of the course grade instead. This is not recommended, however, as the final examination is harder than the midterm.]

FINAL EXAMINATION 50% [84%]
Comprised of 95 multiple-choice questions and 1 essay question. Covers the entire course, including material examined in the midterm, as well as content regarding the film "Inside Job". Although the time limit is more lenient (160 minutes), the questions are more difficult on average. Some particularly challenging ones are marked with an asterisk (*), do leave them until the very end.

MY GRADE
Assignments | 16/16
Midterm | 67/72 (Mean = 53.8, S.D. unknown)
Final Examination | 93/103 (Mean = 66.8, S.D. = 15.1)
Overall | 92.78%
Grade | A

Note: I have never taken an economics course before.
reviews.comment_workload:
On average, one assignment (comprising of questions from the textbook) is released per week, which takes anywhere from 15 mins to 60 mins to complete, due after around one week. As mentioned in the Grading section, you do not have to complete all assignments, though doing so will certainly assist in revising for the midterm and final examination.

It is "mandatory" (according to the professor) to buy the textbook and read it, for a better understanding of the concepts taught in the lecture. Assignment questions are scanned and uploaded to Canvas, so technically you do not require the textbook to secure a good grade.

reviews.author: LuQ
reviews.title: Don't take this if you want to do DDP or minor in Business
reviews.comment_content:
Content is terribly wide, very basic stuff, but just too much to handle within 1 semester. This course is exclusive with both Micro and Macro intro courses. So note that you can't take this if you will do DDP or want to minor in business.
I never took econ before so i basically got screwed over in this course. Especially since this course attracts students who are non-business students and have already done Econ in high school.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very easy at the start of course, then it just gets too the point that he just rushes through the PPT too fast that I couldn't catch up anymore.
The basic rundown is that he talks about the HW at the 1st lecture of the week as HW is given right before class starts on Canvas, then he talks approx 1 CH for the next lecture of the week. So very compact int terms of the actual learning process.
Terrible writing, so make sure you do your own notes on what he wrote on the screen.
Didn't like his pace of teaching at all, he was too slow at the beginning, spent 1 whole lesson on the same concept when going through HW. Then he would be too fast later on during the harder concepts. Terribly rushed in a number of PPTs. Sometimes he would just tell us to read the book as he s scrolled through the PPT.
***Highly recommended to go to lecture when he talks about HW solutions, he welcomes questions then.
reviews.comment_grading:
Honestly not too terrible in the grading part overall.

Weighing: 16% HW (2% per HW with a total of 14 HW, you can do till 8 to get full grades. Note that answers are not graded), 34% Midterm (about 60 MCs and 1 essay), 50% Final (about 90 MCs and 1 essay)
*What's terrible is that he didn't tell us the duration of midterm and final prior, we were only told on the spot...

He said mean is about B-
HW: 100%

Midterm:
Median: 54
SD: 8
My score: 51

Final:
MC:
Mean: 61.96
SD: 12.35
My score: 66

Essay:
Mean: 4.88
SD: 6
My score: 0 (really didn't bother with essay, too much MCs anyway)

I got a B- in the end, honestly expected worse.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 HW a week, sometimes cross-chapters, but reasonable amount only at times. I just did the 1st few and the last few questions to get completion marks.
If you do get the textbook and will make use of it, it's terribly heavy workload to go through what was learnt in class towards the end of the sem. Especially since he explicitly said to go through the textbooks as i've said above.

reviews.author: Ernest2688
reviews.title: don't take even if you have studied econ in dse
reviews.comment_content:
Little micro, (scarcity, opportunity cost, comparative advantage and PPC, Demand and supply)
Macro,( GDP, inflation, real GDP, GDP per capita,  employment, Savings, PAE, money supply, ADAS, exchange rate and trade)
Sounds many right?
yes, it covers mainly all of the macroeconomics syllabus of dse econ.
I think this course are suitable to 2 kind of students

- students who are very interested in economics but unfortunately didn't choose econ or business as your major
-students who got 5 or above in dse econ.
If you are not these 2 kind of students, don't take this course or good luck.
reviews.comment_teaching:
2 lesson per week. Mainly one lesson will teach a new topic, and one lesson will check the ans of the assignment of each chapter.
Better buy the book if you really want to learn the concepts( the PowerPoint slides are not enough)
reviews.comment_grading:
you an choose not to attend midterm exam
and the ratio will be shift to the final exam.
Grading not yet known
reviews.comment_workload:
quite low. you don't even need to attend the lesson.
You only need to summit 8 assignment.  And the quality is not considered.

reviews.author: You know who
reviews.title: interesting but hard to excel this course if you have no Econ background
reviews.comment_content: As a science student, I think the contents are quite interesting. However, when it comes to the concepts related to taxation and margins, it started to become a bit confusing and took me much time to figure them out when studying for finals.
reviews.comment_teaching: By virtue of the fact that I can't stand with her accents and she talked too slow with stutters, I didn't pay attention to her lecturing. This low rating is given for her accents actually.
reviews.comment_grading:
There were some local students who had taken economics in high school but dropped it before DSE(or they got poor results in DSE econ). Those students would probably have some basic knowledge and sense when dealing with the contents. Congrats, this course is suitable for you guys to take. For students who encounter econ topics for the first time, I'm sorry that you have to work harder for exams.
My midterm result is below mean slightly, I got 2 homework with lowest mark and 1 homework with a full mark. Final results were unknown and I forgot the marks for quizzes. At last, I got a B-.
reviews.comment_workload:
There are assignments (~3 assignments?) containing analytical (with contexts) and computational(calculating things like ) questions, approximately 5-10 questions(with sub-questions).
You can of course search for the answers online(really hard to find those free ones) but honestly, you better to do it on your own so that you can deal with the midterms and finals in an easier manner.
There were also 2 pop-up quizzes, I forgot my performances. Yet, I think students who work hard after class should have no problem in performing well on the quizzes.

reviews.author: Jesse
reviews.comment_content:
Most of the content is about Economics covered in DSE.
Only some concepts introduced need you to understand, but it is quite easy.
The concepts are similar and they are all written in the lecture notes.

I. Introduction: basic principles of economics
II. The market system of demand and supply
III. How price regulations and tax policies affect the outcomes of the market
IV. Basic welfare analysis of tax policy
V. The problem areas for the market and government policies to deal with market failure
VI. Competition, monopoly, and the organization of industry
VII. The market for labor
IX. Basic concepts in macroeconomics
VIII. Economic growth
X. The monetary system
XI. Basic concepts of open-economy macroeconomics (if time permits)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Although the instructor got her accent, the teaching was acceptable. She was willing to answer questions.
Another thing is that she uploaded lectures only on the weekend night, which was the night before the lecture held. It was difficult for you to do preparation before the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quizzes 10%
Problem sets 15%
Midterm in class 30%
Final exam (comprehensive) 45%

You only need to attend one of the two quizzes, or you can have both. It will consider your higher score.
I missed the first quiz and I did not study in the second. I don't remember my score.
I got 92% for my midterm exam and 90% for the final.
And I have an A.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was moderate. The assignments could be finished within one day if you knew the concepts. You would not know the exact date of the quiz so it meant you should revise every week to get some preparation if you are a nervous peroson.

reviews.author: CKL
reviews.title: Recommend for science and engineering students
reviews.comment_content:
The content in this semester differs a lot from the previous semesters, perhaps it is due to the change of instructor. The content is simple, similar to HKDSE economics level, but not all topics in HKDSE are included in this course.

I. Introduction: basic principles of economics
II. The market system of demand and supply
III. How price regulations and tax policies affect the outcomes of the market
IV. Basic welfare analysis of tax policy
V. The problem areas for the market and government policies to deal with market failure VI. Competition, monopoly, and the organization of industry
VII. The market for labor
IX. Basic concepts in macroeconomics
VIII. Economic growth
reviews.comment_teaching: I think the teaching was not quite good. First, the professor came from mainland China, so her speaking carried much mainland accent. Sometimes, it was difficult to hear what she said. Moreover, she often uploaded the notes on canvas after a week, so it was quite difficult for an immediate revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Two pop-up quizzes (only the quiz with better performance is included in grade calculation)
15% Three problem sets
30% Midterm exam
45% Comprehensive final exam

I think the grading of this course is quite lenient. Even though I did not study economics in my secondary school, I can still get an A range.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite low. The contend in lectures, so revision does not spend you much time. The main workload is 3 homework sets. There are about 10 long questions in each homework set, some of those may require you to think more deeply, but it can be finished within few hours. Also, you have to attend all lessons because there are 2 pop-up quizzes.

reviews.author: Coral
reviews.title: reg this course if u study econ in dse
reviews.comment_content: dse econ with one or two new topics
reviews.comment_teaching:
very bad
prof.'s spoken english is not that good
and she is just speak out the powerpoint
reviews.comment_grading:
good grade
mid term n final are easy if u hv study econ in dse
no attendance but only 2 popup quiz
if you hv finish one (n got enough mark) u dun hv to go to class anymore
reviews.comment_workload:
3 problem set
2 pop up quiz(only count the higher mark one)
1 mid term
1 final
problem set is easy and the most people got full mark in all the problem set

reviews.author: Bearrr
reviews.comment_content: Basically a half of HKDSE economics. Easy for those who have econmoics base, and still easy for those who haven't.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Strong and unclear mainland accent, hard to understand.
Go to class only because of unannounced quizzes.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grade is quite good.
Hand in 2 problem sets and below 1sd in midterm, got B-.
Didn't take back my quizzes and the marks for final is not released.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 problem sets, total 15%
2 unannounced quizzes, count the higher one 10%
Midterm 30% and final 45%.
Spent about 3-4 hours to read the lecture notes once for midterm and final.

reviews.author: Ar Mong
reviews.title: By someone who doesn't take economic is HKDSE
reviews.comment_content:
The content is generally easy to follow and not hard to understand.
The concepts involved in the course are not difficult at all. However the things you need to memorize is quite a lot.
The course gives you a brief introduction to a lot of things in economics.
As a student has no economics background at all, I can still manage this course throughout this semester.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Li talks kinda slow and makes students to fall asleep easily. She does try to ask more questions and rise the attention, but it doesn't work AT ALL.
Besides, all the mid-term, quizzes, problem sets and final are marked and returned to us in a long time. It takes them a relatively long time to review the above materials. I can only get back my quiz and mid-term in the final study break
reviews.comment_grading:
As a student has no economics background at all, the students who do economics in HKDSE will pull the mean so high that it is very hard to get a good grade.
But if you do study hard and turn in all the problem sets, you should be able to get a good grade. After all, the students take economics in HKDSE are not hard-working. You can out smart them by hard work.
reviews.comment_workload:
In this semester, I had to hand in 3 problem sets(due in 3/5, 4/6, 5/8) which are consist for about 10 questions from the book, it takes me 3 hours to finish one on my own.
There are two quizzes throughout this term and only the one with higher marks is count towards final grades. If you pay attention in the class, the quiz should be easy for you.

reviews.author: maksyu
reviews.title: If you didn't study Econ before, don't expect a good grade
reviews.comment_content:
- Introduction to macroeconomics (the first two (or three) chapters are the same as microeconomics). Good for those who would like to learn Econ but did not take any Econ courses before.

- incredibly easy for those who took Econ in high school

- finish whole textbook (14 units) in one semester. The teaching speed is incredibly fast for those who have never taken Econ.

- Please don't forget to watch the documentary. It will be covered in the exam. (20 marks, essay format)

- you don't have to buy the textbook even if you didn't learn econ before
reviews.comment_teaching:
- A lot of learning freedom!
you are welcome to skip all the lessons if you can self-study. All the learning materials are available before the first lesson. He emphasizes that he will not make the exam unfair to those did not take lessons.

- teaching speed is too fast for those who did not take ECON in high school

- he explains the concept quite clearly

- his tone makes my friends and me sleepy though
reviews.comment_grading:
- Definitely not good for those who didn't take Econ in high school. (Notes: the course quota = 400, so there are rooms for good grades though)

- For those who studied ECON before, it is (according to my friends' experience) extremely easy to get A

Assignments: 16%. 2% (pass/fail) for each assignment up to a maximum of 8 assignments, out of approximately 10.

2 midterm exams, in class: 18% each.
Midterm exams are not cumulative. The first Midterm exam is not compulsory. Missing the midterm exam
No apology is needed if you miss one of the midterm exams (for whatever reason, oversleeping, illness, family emergency, donâ€™t feel like taking the midterm exam), and no penalty is imposed. There is no make-up midterm exam. If you miss a midterm exam, the following rules on re-weighting apply.
If you miss the first midterm (only), they will re-weight the second midterm and the final exam, in proportion to the weight of the second midterm and the final exam, i.e., second midterm = 18% + (18[2nd] / (18[2nd]+38[final])) * 18[1st]%; final = 38% + (38/(18+38))*18%.
If you miss the second midterm (only), all the weight of that goes to the final exam.
If you miss the first and second midterm, the weights of these go to the final exam.

Final exam: 38%. The final exam is cumulative. Date: as determined by the university. Questions from the midterm exams will not be repeated on the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
Completely not heavy

Weekly Assignment:
- does not check whether your answers are correct / whether you finish all the questions
- you don't have to do all the assignments

reviews.author: michaelam
reviews.title: GOOD GRADE COURSE **
reviews.comment_content:
Super basic in the first few chapters but a bit more diffcult in the later chapters
Concepts are SUPER IMPORTANT in this course especially those about interest rates, inflation etc
reviews.comment_teaching: I have attended less than 5 lectures and honestly lectures are boring af and NOT necessnary (no attendance taken)
reviews.comment_grading:
SUPER GOOD GRADE

2 MIDTERMS:
FIRST MT 49/60 (MEAN 47.3)
SECOND MT 51/64 (MEAN 48.5)

1 FINAL:
MC 65/72 (MEAN 54.7)
ESSAY (CHOOSE 1 FROM 2 QS) 20/20 (MEAN:14.3)

FINAL GRADE: B+
(PROF said that the mean grade is B-)
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignments have to be submited through canvas and theres actually a lot of assignments
But the good thing is the TA wont't check what you have written down in ur assignments so basically you can just write anything randomly and you will get FULL MARKS!
Final is CUMULATIVE!
BUT the mc and essay are mainly testing your CONCEPTS so NO NEED to recite everything
You will do well if you have understood the concepts (relatively diffcult to people who have not study econ before but manageable! just google/wiki and you will understand the concepts easily)

reviews.author: Brighton
reviews.title: Good choice for common core if you have studied economics in high school
reviews.comment_content:
Very similar to high school economic syllabus
Problem is that you need to learn a 3-year-curriculum in 1 semester
Piece of cake if you have studied in high school
reviews.comment_teaching:
nice and clear
Ppt includes typical examples which are useful for revision
Skipping lesson will be okay.
Not too much difficult concept need to be explained
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading
Mean around B range
Assignments weigh around 10%
40% mid-term
50% final
reviews.comment_workload:
Not heavy.
Assignmets that you can find answers by google. 5-10 assignment in total.
Syllbus will not accumulate.
Weekly assigements sudmiting in hard copy.

reviews.author: Eclipse
reviews.title: I would say decent? But not the best grading IMO
reviews.comment_content: The content is fairly easy. The course covers stuff that are pretty much present in your high school economics, such as the "7 principles" of economics, the economy in the long run, the economy in the short run and the international economy. The concepts are not hard to understand at all, if you do read the slides and the textbook.
reviews.comment_teaching: The slides are well made, so it is easy to understand the concepts just by reading the slides. The textbooks do have better explanation, but the textbook also sometimes contain extra lines of information that is completely redundant in the face of an examination or real-life application. Use the slides to teach yourself, while clearing any doubts with the textbook.
reviews.comment_grading: From the start he mentions that he will place the mean at B-. For myself, I got 66/70 for mid-terms, 120/130 for final, 16/16 for homework and still got an A. If you really want that high A range then you should really work for it.
reviews.comment_workload: Due to the weekly homework that you have to complete, the workload is there. But if you are a hard-working student (that you are "supposed" to be) then I guess it isn't too much.

reviews.author: Vincent_us
reviews.comment_content: The first three chapters are about microeconomics, and the other eleven chapters are about macroeconomics. The content is abundant and useful, especially for students from science and engineering. In the last two lectures of this course, students have to watch a movie called 'inside job' and this will be examined in the final.
reviews.comment_teaching: A German professor whose English is easy to understand.
reviews.comment_grading: Normally, the number of quota can be 400, which means there will be lots of quota for good grades. It's easy to get an A range grade. If you want an A+, just review for several days before the midterm and the final.
reviews.comment_workload: Nearly zero workload. You can even skip the midterm exam without informing the professor.

reviews.author: Jackie
reviews.title: Introductory course for beginners in Economics
reviews.comment_content: The course covered basic topics in Economics. The content is similar to DSE Economics, I haven't taken Economics in DSE though, I heard it from my friend. The contents include comparative advantage, supply and demand, labour market, monetary policy and fiscal policy etc. Personally I found it not very difficult to grasp if you are hard-working enough to read all of the powerpoints and skim the textbook. However you need to pay attention to calculations since the final asked a lot about that. at almost the end of the lecture a movie about the financial crisis of USA will be played. Pay attention to the movie since the final asked quite a lot about that. Better watch it again in idol time.
reviews.comment_teaching: Holzs' voice is a bit dull but his English is fluent and easy to understand. He was quite eager to answer students' questions and will use role playing games to let us understand the concepts better. Also, some concepts from the powerpoints and textbooks were not really correct and he explained the mistakes clearly. However since he didn't really speak up and his voice is boring, not many students listen to his lectures. He even said we didn't actually need to attend the lectures at the beginning of the course since he thought the materials on canvas are adequate.
reviews.comment_grading: The midterm exam was MC only, but the final exam consisted of a few short questions and 100 MCs. I think some students got a really high grade since I got a A- only when I got more than 85 as my final total. However I do think that you can get a good grade if you pay enough time to understand the concepts thoroughly.
reviews.comment_workload:
You will have to hand in assignments every week online, which are actually questions in the textbook. Don't worry, many people have the answers of the assignments and Holtz would scan all the questions up canvas so you dun actually need to buy the book. Also, the assignments were graded quite loosely and you can get full marks already by handing in something.
The midterms and finals were not very difficult but there were a bit of time pressure since you would need to finish 60 MCs in 60 minutes in the midterm, and 100 MCs together with 3 short questions in 120 minutes.

reviews.comment_content:
- basic macroeconomics and most content should be  under the DSE syllabus
-no attendance  no prs
-A documentary ("Inside Job")  will be included in the course, which is VERY IMPORTANT i think as final essay question will mainly base on it.

generally the content in easy

-except the lectures with showing the film i think theres no need to attain the lecture

-required to complete 8 assignments out of 12 and the assignments are marked base on COMPLETION.
-never blank any question, even you dun know, still write something even it's nonsense or shxt
-eg. i have submitted many assignment like this:

however I still get the full completion marks:)

reviews.author: M.T
reviews.comment_content:
It teaches basic macroeconomics and most content are covered in DSE syllabus. So anyone who have studied econ in secondary schools can easily catch up with it.

At the first lecture, the professor said "If you don't want to come to lecture, then don't come" so basically you can self-study the entire course.

A documentary ("Inside Job") is watched during the last few lessons, it basically covers what exactly happened during the Subprime mortgage crisis in 2007-08. It is strongly recommend to watch it in lecture and the content will be tested in final exam.

Important : Make sure you obtain all answers for the movie's assignment, there were 20 marks in the final asking about the film!

P.S. This film won the 83th Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature. Simply a masterpiece.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor is willing to answer student's questions on or after the class.

There are two lectures per week and one of the lecture will  be used for assignment solution. The professor will explain the questions in details.

The voice of professor seems a bit dull.
reviews.comment_grading:
I believe the grading is good even I have never studied econ in secondary school.

Assignment 16%  (2% Each, you can get full marks by completing 8 out of 12 assignments)

Midterm 34% / 0%
Final 50% / 84%  
(You may choose not to take the midterm)

My score :
Assignment 16/16
Midterm       65/70  (~+1.4 - 1.5 s.d.)
Final          111/130
-------------------------
Grade : A
(Never studied econ)
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is very light since you are only required to complete 8 assignments out of 12 and the assignments are marked base on completion.

So if you have submit the assignments, you will get full mark from it. (Even if you write nonsense)

reviews.author: cwl.Alex
reviews.title: Not Bad
reviews.comment_content:
Fundamental theories of microeconomics and macroeconomics, learning the supply-and-demand relationship, some basic secondary-school-level economic stuff.

Topic:
1.10 principles of economics
2.Demand, supply, equilibrium
3.elasticity
4.government policies: price floor/ceiling, tax
5.welfare economics: consumer/producer/total surplus
6.deadweightloss
7.international trade
8.externalities
9.public goods and common resources
10.cost of production
11.firms in competitive markets
12.monopoly
13.labor market, supply and demand
14.discrimination
15.measuring a nation's income: gdp
16.measuring the cost of living: cpi
reviews.comment_teaching:
She has a strong mainland accent, but it is still acceptable.
Teaching at a smooth pace and active students on Zoom contributes to a great learning experience.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Two pop-up quizzes
15% Three Problem sets
25% Midterm exam (on Canvas)
50% Comprehensive final exam (on Canvas)

I got A- despite having scores around the mean value in both midterm and exams.
reviews.comment_workload:
Three Problem sets, 5 points each & 2 pop-up quizzes (thus somehow requires attendance)

I would recommend doing the assessment by yourself first, then comparing it with a source and doing the correction before handing it in. The score of 3 HWs is very high (~100), so you would not want to risk it.

The quizzes are unannounced so you need to be ready anytime and attend each and every lesson.

reviews.author: Ryan Chan
reviews.title: Macro-economy
reviews.comment_content:
A good CC course.

NO need to buy any textbook, but you may want an online software version in the school library if you want a more detailed explanation.

zoom exam due to COVID-19.

Coverage:
L1: Intro of some econ concepts
L2: Comparative advantage
L4: Supply and Demand
L5: GDP and unemployment
L6: Inflation
L7: economic growth, productivity, and living standard
L8: workers, wages, and unemployment
L9: saving and capital formation
L10: money, prices and the Federal Reserve
L11: Financial Markets and International Capital Flows
L12: short term economic fluctuation
L13: spending and output in the short run
L14: role of Fed, money demand and money supply
L15: Aggregate Demand and Aggregate supply
L16: Internaitonal Trade and Trade Policy
L17: exchange rate and open economy

film: inside job (include in the final exam)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Go through the ans of assignments and mini-assignments, and then go through the lecture notes.
sometimes, he would play videos related to the lecture materials, quite interesting!
You can skip all lectures as you like. NO attendance.
reviews.comment_grading:
-24% for weekly assignment, only need to do 8 out of them, you got full mark as long as you have done it

-8% for weekly mini-assignment, only need to do 8 out of them, you got full mark as long as you have done it,

-38% = 2 x 19% for 2 mid-terms: you can all in final and skip all the 2 midterms. The midterm weighting will automatically shift to the final. ALL MCs, time pressure: ~1mins per question

-30% for final: ALL MCs, time pressure: ~1mins per question
(if you skip all midterms, the final would become 68%.

I got a B for having a mean in midterms, exam.
Good grade!
reviews.comment_workload:
not much
2 hw weekly for assignment and mini -assignment.
Better to do all of the assignments because most of the questions in mid-term and final are similar to the assignments. For, mini assignment, comparatively not important but you can get a better understanding of the econ knowledge.

reviews.comment_content: Fair. It is like a basic introduction of econ. If you have studied econ before then you should be fine. I did not study econ in my dse but i still handled the course quite okay lah so no worries.
reviews.comment_teaching: He is quite funny and tried to interact with the students, I like his teaching, he is easy to approach too if you need him.
reviews.comment_grading: Reasonable, this course does not count attendance so if you have studied econ before you can ignore all lectures and simply study yourself and appear in the mid-term and final exam. I only took MT because of the special situation this sem and I used my MT mark directly as my final grade (plus my assignments, I should have gotten full mark because as long as you  have handed in sth you will get full mark in that assignment, you just need to complete 8 out of 12 assignments to get a full mark.) I did not even reach mean but I was close like within 1SD at last I got a B, so I think the grading is quite fair.
reviews.comment_workload: Not must workload I would say, he gives assignment nearly every lecture but you just need to complete 8 out of all. You get full mark even if you get all wrong lol, so I guess it is not too harsh. No project, no presentation, no quizzes.

reviews.author: Bread
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers some very basic economics concepts. More specifically, this course is an introduction to macroeconomics.
The course also covers a documentary, 'Inside Job', which is about the 2008 Financial Crisis.
Overall, if you have studied economics in high school, you will have a huge advantage, but it is still possible to do well if you have no prior knowledge in economics--quite a lot of the content can be deduced from common sense, and others require memorization.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professors mainly follows the powerpoint only, so nothing remarkable really happens. Thanks in part to the 'active' participation of the students in class, the lectures tends to be rather boring. In other words, since attendance is not compulsory, it is definitely viable to self-study the contents of this course. (Given that I missed half of the lectures myself, I can verify this).
If I am to attend only 1 lecture for this course, it would probably be the final on 'Inside Job', where he gives a bit more detailed explanation on some of the topics such as leverage, which turns out was covered rather extensively in the final exam. Other than that, since you can watch the documentary on your own, you really do not have to attend the lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
The score calculation is as follow:
Assignment: 16% (You do not need to do all 12 assignments, around 8-9 is ok)
Mid-Term: 34% (You can choose to not attend Mid-Term, then it will not count towards your overall score)
Final: 50% (84% if you choose not to attend the Mid-Term. It is definitely viable--I know people who does this and get good score. It just depends if you want to gamble your entire grade on 1 exam)
The mean, according to the course introduction document, is B-. However, as stated on the document, it is only true 'when in doubt', and the actual mean can be higher or lower. Given the scores shown in Canvas. I would guess the mean is B, but I cannot give a definite answer on that.
reviews.comment_workload: The weekly assignments usually consist of around 8 questions from the textbook "Principles on Macroeconomics". The work load is quite heavy...if you take the assignments seriously. However, the TAs probably do not even bother to read your answer, so as long as you hand in something, you will get 2/2 for your assignment. Apparently, some students even directly copy-paste the previous assignment onto the new assignment, and still get 2/2, so yes, you can see how 'seriously' the TAs are.
